user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following MHD_send_iovec_ code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 2.2.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of MHD_send_iovec_.
```c
ssize_t
MHD_send_iovec_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                 struct MHD_iovec_track_ *const r_iov,
                 bool push_data)
{
#ifdef MHD_VECT_SEND
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
  bool use_iov_send = true;
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
#endif /* MHD_VECT_SEND */

  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->rp.resp_iov.iov);
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->rp.response->data_iov);
  mhd_assert (connection->rp.resp_iov.cnt > connection->rp.resp_iov.sent);
#ifdef MHD_VECT_SEND
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  use_iov_send = use_iov_send &&
                 (0 == (connection->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS));
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
#ifdef _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED
  use_iov_send = use_iov_send && (connection->daemon->sigpipe_blocked ||
                                  connection->sk_spipe_suppress);
#endif /* _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
  if (use_iov_send)
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
  return send_iov_nontls (connection, r_iov, push_data);
#endif /* MHD_VECT_SEND */

#if ! defined(MHD_VECT_SEND) || defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
  return send_iov_emu (connection, r_iov, push_data);
#endif /* !MHD_VECT_SEND || HTTPS_SUPPORT
          || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The project contains calls like mhd_assert(...); in MHD_send_iovec_ which, given the macro definition #define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0), expand to the expression statement ((void)0);. Those statements are executed but have no effect and could be removed without changing program behaviour, i.e. they are dead code. Therefore Rule 2.2 is violated.
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_send_iovec_:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: The report is not correct. MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 forbids ‘‘dead code’’ defined as an operation that is executed and whose removal would not affect program behaviour. Although mhd_assert expands to the no‑op expression statement ((void)0); that expansion is intentionally used to neutralize assertions. Whether removing that statement would or would not affect program behaviour is not something that can be assumed: in embedded systems even a no‑op can affect timing, optimisation boundaries, or other observable behaviour. Thus you cannot categorically classify those macro expansions as ‘‘dead code’’ under the rule. In practice this pattern (assertions expanding to ((void)0)) is the standard way to disable assertions and is not considered a Rule 2.2 violation unless you can prove removal has no effect. Therefore the agent A claim is incorrect.
